Assistant: Sure! Lions are one of the largest and most iconic species of terrestrial carnivores, native to Africa.  These animals have commonly been portrayed as majestic and powerful, due to their impressive physical strength and social organization.  Lions are actually rather shy and elusive creatures though, spending the majority of their time in secluded protected areas such as forests and grasslands.  Their behavior typically consists of resting and sleeping during the day, while hunting and patrolling their territory at night.  Lions’ social structures are complex and highly territorial, forming prides which are governed by a dominant male lion known as the “pride leader.”  Females generally congregate in these prides to raise their young and participate in elaborate territorial defense strategies against competing groups.  Lions are currently classified as a vulnerable species by the International Union for Conservation of Nature, with the primary threat to their population coming from extensive loss and fragmentation of their natural habitat.  They are also often hunted for their valuable pelts in many parts of Africa.  In addition to their widespread public appeal, lions are an important symbol and totem in many African and Asian cultures, representing power and strength.

instruction:
Human: How can I make my own mead?

Assistant: Mead is a honey wine, typically made by fermenting a solution of honey and water with yeast. To make your own mead, you’ll need a large open pot, at least 5 gallons (19 liters) in size, a strainer, and clean 5-gallon (19-liter) glass bottles with caps. You’ll also need honey and water, and a packet of yeast. Start by mixing 2 gallons (7.5 liters) of water with 1 gallon (3.8 liters) of honey. Add the packet of yeast and stir until it’s fully dissolved. Pour the mixture into your pot, put the lid on, and set the pot aside in a warm, draft-free location for about 2 weeks, until the mixture begins to ferment and has a sweet smell. Strain the liquid into a clean pot, then bottle it and put the bottles in a cool, dark place to age. The longer it sits, the stronger and more flavorful the mead will be. To drink it, pour a glass and enjoy!

However, yes, it was primarily celebrated by the working class, and by the time it became important, most of the UK was still agrarian and dominated by the working class.  The class issue seems to have been less important than the general concern for working people, in some ways.  The country was still very poor at this time, in fact the UK was one of the poorest nations in Europe, and much of its wealth was still in the hands of a few powerful, wealthy families and landowners.  However, by Christmas time, most people had work and all the basic necessities of life, so the holiday offered a way to give people time off from their usual working, but still get a chance to spend some time celebrating with friends and family.
instruction:
Human: What is Boxing Day?

Assistant: “Boxing Day” is a well-known, traditional holiday celebrated in the United Kingdom and a few other places, including some Commonwealth nations.  It has two general functions.  One function is to mark the formal end of the Christmas season; people often celebrate Christmas and New Years on the same day, but the day after Christmas is considered to mark the end of Christmas, and boxing day celebrates that.  The second is to give people the opportunity to exchange gifts.  Traditionally it is a chance for family and friends to give and receive gifts, sometimes in the form of “Christmas boxes”, but this is no longer the case.

Human: When did this tradition start?

Assistant: It’s a bit unclear exactly how far back this tradition goes, but it’s known to have been a part of the Christmas season since at least the 1700s.  There is a story that the tradition was created by a man named Henry Upjohn, a wealthy English banker, who gave the young servant boys who worked at his house a day off on December 26th each year to provide them an opportunity to exchange small gifts with their friends and families.  This would be unlikely to be what the earliest holiday was like though, since by the time Upjohn began the holiday in the 1700s, people would already have had at least one day to exchange gifts, in which case the holiday would have been about enjoying an extra day off and some rest.  This would also have been an entirely optional holiday, unlike boxing day, which has always been an important part of Christmas in the UK, not just something that is sometimes celebrated.  Though there is some evidence that Christmas and boxing day were only celebrated every other year, or occasionally skipped entirely, before the Industrial Revolution, when some people in the UK were rich enough to be able to buy a lot of gifts and wealthy enough to hire a lot of servants.

The practice of shifting the clock forward in the spring and backward in the fall is intended to reduce the overall energy consumption for illumination during these seasons.  The overall aim of DST is to save energy while also allowing for longer periods of sunlight in the afternoon during the warmer months.

“Composting materials like coffee grinds or spent brewers’ grains offers food for beneficial microorganisms and, in turn, encourages these microorganisms to consume composting ingredients that are less attractive to them.

A study conducted by the California Polytechnic State University found that when brewers’ grains are added to compost with nitrogen-rich food waste like coffee grinds, the nitrogen-rich materials “help create more favorable conditions for bacteria to break down the food waste.”

In a separate research study, the grinds from spent coffee grounds were found to be more effective than shredded wood, black plastic, or sawdust as a soil amendment. Specifically, they’re a great source of calcium and magnesium, which “improve soil structure, water retention and aeration, and overall plant health.”

Since composting is one of the most environmentally friendly ways to get rid of food waste and unwanted items, coffee grounds might just be a sustainable choice for those looking to expand their green practices.”

output: Assistant: True.  Certain types of germs are more difficult to kill, like the spores of some molds or fungi, but otherwise they can kill pretty much all germs.
instruction:
Human: When I clean, some cleaners will have instructions for disinfection versus sterilization. What is there difference between disinfection and sterilization

Assistant: In general, a disinfectant will have more complete and diverse molecules than a sterilizer, which is generally intended to stop just a few specific diseases.  In terms of germs, germicides have compounds that kill specific types of bacteria.  Disinfectants, like bleach, have a broad range of molecular structures that can react with almost any surface, or kill almost any type of bacteria.  Sterilizers are more difficult to manufacture and can harm the environment when waste or harmful by-products are released.  For example, many people mistakenly think that silver works as a sterilizer because it's “naturally sterile”, when it actually kills germs because it is toxic and you have to constantly keep it clean.  The most common sterilizers are hydrogen peroxide and alcohol.

Human: Which one is better at completely getting rid of microbes

output: Assistant: They don’t move very slowly. They travel about 300 miles per hour.  But they are very large so it feels like they are not moving at all.  The spiral shape of a typhoon also makes it look like it is not moving, because the arms of the spiral swirl around but don’t go anywhere. instruction:
Human: How are typhoons formed?

Assistant: They’re formed when the ocean heats up in a spiral pattern.  When the water temperature goes over 86°F, the ocean is too warm for there to be as many clouds or thunderstorms as there normally are.  So a lot of water evaporates and turns into a hot, rising layer of air, which cools down once it gets into the upper atmosphere.  That cooling process creates a lot of condensation, which forms clouds, which in turn create rain and snow.  And rain can cause runoff, which causes the ocean to rise and lower, which creates stronger winds and can lead to flooding.  When the winds grow strong enough, they can reach hurricane strength, even if the ocean temperature hasn’t increased all that much.  The hurricane then grows to a typhoon.

Human: That's scary stuff. Where do typhoons get their fast-moving winds?

Assistant: We don’t know much about the inner workings of hurricanes or typhoons, but it is hypothesized that the temperature difference from cold to warm water (called thermal gradient) can produce strong winds.  Air can be warm or cold when it rises up from the ocean or falls down towards it, and so the updraft or downdraft can become a strong wind and cause rotation.  That rotation is thought to create the strong winds of hurricanes and typhoons.

Human: I see. How then does a typhoon travel from one point to another?

Assistant: They move by getting hit with winds that push them in that direction.  When they get really strong, these winds can have the power to create waves that can even reach up to 30 feet high.  Once a typhoon travels far enough from the ocean, the winds and waves die down because there isn’t much water to continue to act as a pressure source.  But we still sometimes get big waves because of the strong winds and the swirling ocean currents.  And the tornadoes and hailstorms that form in strong winds can often travel hundreds of miles.

It’s also important to consider the type of wood required for the structure of the deck.  Here are three main types of woods used for deck and porch construction:

1   Cedar and Western Red Cedar are heavy and soft woods with a reddish brown color.  These types of wood are known for their durability, versatility, attractive color, and ease of staining.

2   Pressure treated lumber or PSL is made of weakened wood that has been chemically treated.  PSL comes in a variety of colors that stain and water nicely with little maintenance.  It’s your safest bet for areas that must be durable and long lasting.

3   Pressure Treated Lumber (Heavy Decking) comes in wide plies, is low in cost, and has a long shelf life.  It is also resistant to dampness, mold, and insects.  However, it has a tendency of warping, splintering, brittling, and cracking, so extreme temperatures and/or outdoor conditions are not ideal.

Human: What causes wildfires to spread faster?

Assistant: Fire always spreads faster when the bush or forest it’s burning is dry. The common reason for forests to become dry is drought and/or strong winds, especially during the hottest and driest days and months of the year in most regions. During the drought, the normal moisture in the leaves and bark is reduced, and it’s also harder for the plants and trees in the forest (or bush) to recover that moisture when the rain falls. When fire comes nearby, the intense heat causes the plants and trees to desiccate even more quickly, making them extremely dry and thus more flammable. Hence, drought and strong winds will cause wildfires to be more intense and spread faster, and any nearby fires will also spread more easily. Hope this helps!

Human: So there is a huge risk for wildfires when there is high winds and a drought occurring.

Assistant: Yes, that’s true. Dry plants often need very strong gusts of wind to catch fire, because they can’t accumulate enough energy for the plants to ignite. However, when wildfires do start, they run the risk of spreading farther and burning more plants because of the strong winds. And in case of a drought, there’s the added risk of having dry plants throughout the forests and bush, not just a few plants here and there. It's also important to note that even light winds and trees with a small amount of moisture can cause fires to spread. So even with low winds and a little bit of moisture, if the wildfires start, they will spread because of the heat the fire generates.

Assistant: This is a famous historical trial that pitted evolutionary theory against religion. The Scopes Monkey Trial occurred on July 10, 1925. In the trial, a high school teacher was on trial for teaching evolutionary theory (specifically, the theory of evolution by natural selection) to high school students, a science subject he was authorized to teach. The defence was made by Clarence Darrow, the first and perhaps most famous of the American Attorneys for the people. He argued that evolution was a true science and that teaching it did not violate the bible’s creation myth.

However, the prosecution was made by William Jennings Bryan, three times Democratic presidential candidate.  Bryan represented the view of creationism and natural selection, and argued that the teaching of evolution should be forbidden because it contradicted the Genesis account in the bible. 

In the end, the jury ruled in favour of the defence, but the trial was remarkable in that it demonstrated the conflict between religious teachings and scientific evidence, and it made clear the rise of the United States into the 20th century.

This is “imposter syndrome” because of the way that it’s commonly referred to as “imposter syndrome”, but what it’s actually about is that you’re feeling like a fake, when you actually are a real person with real skills.
instruction:

It often seems like people might get it because of their confidence issues.  But it’s not really about confidence, per se, it’s about feeling like you’re faking it and any day now they’ll find out you’re a fraud.

Here’s an example of what might cause someone to feel this way.  I’ll take one of our messages from a human with a question, and show you the kind of communication that goes on with our assistant in the exchange:

You’ll probably then have to be patient, while I go back to the same source that I originally looked in, and I’ll look again.  In this way, if I am unsuccessful in the first few tries, there is a process of trial and error involved.  However, if I were to understand what you mean, and I give you back the answer on the first try, you’ll know that I actually had what you wanted all along. Some common causes of hair loss are:

Male-pattern baldness - Men are genetically predisposed to it.
Alopecia areata - Loss of hair in an area that is round and bald with a smooth border.
Alopecia totalis - Loss of all the scalp hair.
Traction alopecia - Losing hair where hair is pulled very tightly such as in braids, ponytails, cornrows, etc.
Trichotillomania - Repeated pulling of hair.
Trichotis - An area of hair loss that's round and blunt.
Tinea capitis - Scalp fungus infection

If any of these cause you concern, and you want to try treatments, there are several that might help. Many of these treatments have risks and side effects, so I can tell you about them so you can make an informed decision.

Minoxidil may be combined with AHA, and finasteride.
Nioxin and Nioxin Forte - Products that aid hair regrowth.
Depilatories - Products that pull hairs out and make them fall out faster.
Cortisone injections - Prescribed by a doctor for stronger types of hair loss.
Hair transplant - Procedure that involves a piece of skin containing hair is implanted onto the head to fill in the hair loss area.
Follicular unit extraction - Procedure to pull hairs from your own scalp to cover bald areas.

Every time the timer goes off, reset it and work for another 25 minutes.  Once the time limit is up, stop working and do something for 15 minutes that isn’t related to work.  Then reset the timer and do another 25-minute work session.  This is basically a 4-hour work session, but you divide it up into smaller work blocks.  The goal is to keep doing these short work sessions until you finish your project, or until the time limit runs out.  The key to this technique is that every time the timer goes off, you need to refocus on the task at hand.

output:
Assistant: The current accepted theory of the big bang is based on observations of the light emitted from the earliest objects in the Universe, that are known as “cosmic microwave background radiation”, or “CMB” for short.  This light has been traveling for billions of years, so it was formed at the time of the big bang, and gives us information about what happened then.

A key insight of the theory is that the Universe is expanding and has been doing so for the past 15 billion years.  That’s to say, the space between every pair of objects in the Universe is getting bigger, and it used to be smaller.  Also, for the past 3-4 billion years, the expansion has been speeding up.  Astronomers have been able to measure this using the red shift of light from galaxies: redder light indicates that they are moving away from us.  And we know how far apart galaxies were in the past, so this gives a direct measurement of how fast the Universe is expanding.

And we also know what the Universe was like right after the big bang: almost all the matter and energy of the Universe was located in a tiny volume that contained a very high-energy, highly-compressed state.  This state was the only state possible at that time.

Many ideas have been proposed to explain what happened next, but the most well-supported explanation is that the Universe initially expanded so fast that at the early stages it almost immediately decoupled from the high-energy state that existed right after the big bang, and the energy of the high-energy state was transformed into other forms of energy: mostly light.  And this light, the CMB, is what we detect today.

We also know that the Universe is expanding, and was denser and hotter in the past.  This allows us to use the expansion rate as a “clock” to calculate the distance between two objects at any given time, by measuring how much more distant they are now.  This can be applied to measure how far away the CMB was when it emitted light, and thereby to calculate its temperature when it was emitted.  According to the model, the CMB is uniform and was close to 3,000K (or 3,000 degrees Celsius) when it was emitted.

We can also calculate how long the Universe has been in a “reheating phase” since the big bang, since the Universe is currently around 4,000K.  This allows us to calculate how long the Universe has been in its current state, and how long it took to cool down enough for the CMB to form.  It took around 300,000 years for the Universe to cool enough to be able to form the CMB.

And finally, by comparing the age of the Universe to the time that light has traveled since the big bang, we can calculate how far away objects in the Universe are now.  (The standard model predicts that the radius of the Universe is 2.5 times its age, in meters.  The current estimate for the age of the Universe is around 13.7 billion years, so the radius of the Universe is about 45 billion light years.)

Preheat oven to 425 degrees

Prepare a crust with a mixture of 3/4 cup shortening and 1/2 cup of flour, lightly kneaded with 1/2 cup of granulated sugar, a pinch of salt, and a teaspoon of baking powder.

Roll out into a circle and place on a foil-lined cookie sheet.

Bake at 425 degrees for 5 to 7 minutes.

Combine 4 cups of brown sugar, 3/4 cup white sugar, and 1/2 cup butter in a medium saucepan.

Stirring over medium heat until mixture is melted, and there is no longer visible trace of granulated sugar.

Add 3 eggs, 1 teaspoon vanilla, 1/4 teaspoon salt, and 1 tablespoon rum.

Whisk and continue to cook until mixture thickens, about 2 minutes.

Remove from heat and stir in 3/4 cup flour.

Gradually fold in 1 1/2 cups pecans, and pour into pie crust.

Top with dollop of whipped cream and pecan halves.

Bake at 350 degrees for 40 minutes.

Cut and enjoy!

- 2 eggs

Allow the filling to sit in the refrigerator for a couple hours to allow the flavors to develop.

Roll out a pie crust into a circle, then line a 10 inch pie pan with it.

Sprinkle with remaining chopped pecans.

output: Assistant: Following the political consolidation of Anglo-Saxon England by Aethelstan, the Viking raiding and settlement threat diminished, although some persisting Norse influence can still be observed in the English language and culture.  The Norse population of England slowly assimilated into Anglo-Saxon society, and formed the ethnic and cultural basis of the modern English people.  The Danelaw region of England was eventually officially incorporated under the administration of the unified Anglo-Saxon kingdom, although local autonomy and traditions of Norse culture remained in these areas.

This was a group of seven smaller kingdoms that were formed after the decline of the Roman Empire and the collapse of effective central authority and control. This was also a period of significant Viking raiding and settlement in the area, which had a significant impact on the development of the English language and culture.

Human: Which parts of England were settled by Vikings?

Assistant: The Viking raiding and settlement regime across most of England was quite extensive, with some regions facing repeated or extended periods of raids and settlements.  Key parts of the English Midlands, North East, and North West were all significantly affected by Viking influence, with many place and personal names containing Norse elements or etymology.  Significant Viking settlements were also established in these areas in the form of “Danelaw” territories, which were independent north-eastern English kingdoms subject to Viking rule. More remote regions of England were less extensively affected by Viking raids and settlement, but nonetheless the Viking period left a significant cultural imprint on the English people and society.

Human: When did England become the territory it is today?

Assistant: England was formed as a unified kingdom by the 11th century Anglo-Saxon king Aethelstan, following the regional consolidation of minor kingdoms and extensive Viking settlement across most of the country.  This unification process was gradually consolidated during the following centuries, and the monarchy and central administration was further strengthened under the rule of the Norman Kings from the 11th to 12th centuries.  Later centralization efforts were continued under the rule of the Tudor dynasties from the later 15th century, which led to the eventual establishment of the modern unitary British state under the reign of Queen Elizabeth I in the 16th century.

For example, having a partner who is in a mutually monogamous relationship can eliminate the risk of transmission; using a condom during sex can reduce the risk of contracting either virus; and getting tested and treated for STDs can reduce the risk of HIV and hepatitis B transmission from other partners.

Human: What are the symptoms of carpal tunnel syndrome?

Assistant: Carpal tunnel syndrome is a physical condition in which pressure on the median nerve, which runs through the wrist to the hand, causes a range of symptoms such as pain or tingling in the hands and fingers, with the forearm or neck also commonly affected.  Symptoms may include a burning or itching sensation in the hands and fingers, pain and weakness for making a fist or gripping, numbness or burning in the thumb, index and middle fingers, pain in the neck or shoulder, and sometimes difficulty sleeping.  To be diagnosed with carpal tunnel syndrome, a range of less severe symptoms should occur along with any of the following in any of the four limbs: numbness, tingling, and pain in the hands or wrists that are relieved by rest (such as the night), and which worsen with use.  Physical exam findings of carpal tunnel syndrome typically include sensory changes to light touch, as well as to two-point discrimination and to vibration disturbances.  The neurologic examination may reveal weakness, decrease in range of motion, or decreased reflexes.  Less commonly, muscle atrophy or snapping may be seen in the affected hand.  X-rays of the hands may be performed to exclude other conditions, but they are not otherwise

- Burning or tingling sensation in the hands and fingers

- Difficulty making a fist or gripping objects
- Pain and/or tenderness of the wrist
- Weakness in the hand or fingers
- Pain or tingling shooting into the neck or shoulder
- Sleep disturbance due to pain or tingling sensations
